Crimes.Crime_Name: Flight risk under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Tursunbayev was conditionally released due to flight risk; requests to vary conditions were partially granted or denied based on risk assessment and compliance history.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Compliance with prior release conditions considered in decision-making
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of decisions to vary release conditions
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration detention decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Interpol Red Notice, embezzlement charges in Kazakhstan, compliance history
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Applications for variation partially granted or denied
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Balancing individual liberty with legitimate flight risk concerns; decisions adequately justified
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Division, Federal Court (on judicial review)

Crimes.Violation_Type: Flight risk due to outstanding criminal charges abroad
Crimes.Application_Facts: Tursunbayev subject to Interpol Red Notice and extradition request due to embezzlement charges in Kazakhstan; deemed unlikely to appear for admissibility hearing
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: History of compliance with release conditions assessed
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging continued detention and conditional release
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court's role in reviewing immigration detention decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Interpol Red Notice, Kazakhstani embezzlement charges, prior decisions
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Release conditions maintained or modified based on ongoing flight risk
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Greater freedom of movement and reduced supervision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Minister must demonstrate continued flight risk; no requirement for material change in circumstances
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Decisions grounded in evidence and legal principles; no error found in assessment

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Criminal accusation leading to immigration consequences
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether release conditions should be varied given serious financial crime allegations
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 58
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Immigration Division decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Accusation of $20 million embezzlement in Kazakhstan supported by Interpol Red Notice
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No error found in refusal to fully relax release conditions
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Minister to justify continued flight risk status
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Seriousness of underlying charges affects credibility of appearance assurance
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Individual may be detained or conditionally released if unlikely to appear for hearing
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged abuse of discretion in denying variation of conditions
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Interpol Red Notice, magnitude of alleged embezzlement, lack of strong ties to Canada
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA framework for managing flight risks among permanent residents
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Requests to vary conditions based on rehabilitation and compliance
Crimes.Evidence_Type: International arrest notice, foreign criminal charges
Crimes.Outcome: Denied in part; partial modifications allowed

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Extradition-related immigration detention based on international corruption charges
Crimes.Outcome: Detention and restrictive release conditions upheld
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request to reduce restrictions due to compliance and low immediate risk
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and Canada’s cooperation with international justice mechanisms
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Immigration Division imposed and maintained strict release conditions
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Canada Border Services Agency, Immigration Division, Federal Court
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Permanent resident facing removal due to criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Risk_Factor: High flight risk due to severity of charges and foreign prosecution interest
Crimes.Credibility: Charges supported by Interpol Red Notice; credibility of non-appearance concern high
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Flight risk linked to serious transnational corruption
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Individual accused of state-related financial misconduct

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Detention review
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Assessment of flight risk and alternatives to detention
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Alleged misrepresentations in immigration documents

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to adequately assess alternatives to detention

Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Likelihood of appearing at admissibility hearing
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Release unless unlikely to appear (Section 58 IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of leaving Kazakhstan and financial resources
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside, remitted for new detention review
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in immigration documentation

Crimes.Violation_Type: Flight risk and failure to comply with immigration conditions

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubted likelihood of compliance with reporting obligations
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Unlikely to appear or danger to public

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Detention review and release conditions

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to leave Canada after temporary status expired

Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Credible evidence indicating danger to national security
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Prolonged detention, potential reassociation with extremist networks
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Alleged ties with terrorist organizations posing threat to Canada's security
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible intelligence; concerns about surety credibility
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Reliance on confidential evidence and credibility of sureties

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns regarding reliability of sureties but individual concedes risk

Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Continued detention or release under strict conditions

Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Individual poses danger to national security
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Potential reassociation with extremist groups, credibility concerns

Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Duration of detention, disruption of contacts, willingness to comply with conditions
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 83(3)
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: IRPA s. 83(3), Charkaoui v Canada (Citizenship and Immigration)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of security certificate and detention conditions
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Release under stringent house arrest-like conditions

Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Assessed as dangerous due to alleged membership in proscribed organization
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Potential radicalization or re-engagement upon release
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Alleged membership in Egyptian Islamic Al Jihad, a designated terrorist entity
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Conceded involvement posing danger to national security
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Supported by intelligence; no direct evidence of violence
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of public evidence linking to violent acts; reliance on classified material
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Classified intelligence, investigative findings
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Individual’s claims tempered by prolonged detention and lack of deportation pathway
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Extended detention period, absence of immediate removal, acceptance of monitoring
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities under immigration security provisions
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 83(3)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Detention based on alleged terrorist affiliation without criminal conviction
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Conditional release with electronic monitoring and supervision

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Comply with Removal Orders

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to appear for removal interviews, lied about identity, and has a history of non-compliance

Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Ineffective past bonds and lack of credible bondsmen

Crimes.Evidence_Used: History of non-compliance, proposed bondsmen details

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant deemed not credible due to past lies and non-compliance

Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Release from detention or alternative conditions
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness under section 248 of the Regulations
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Flight risk outweighs length of detention; alternatives insufficient

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making Untrue Statements to Canadian Officials
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Whether the conditions of Mr. Harkat's release should be modified based on his credibility and potential danger to national security
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Modification of release conditions under IRPA §82
Crimes.Outcome: Some conditions were relaxed, such as being home alone under specific conditions, while others remained unchanged
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Harkat was deemed untruthful in past testimonies, raising concerns about his credibility
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Mr. Harkat sought a review of his release conditions under IRPA §82(4)
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Conditions must neutralize danger to national security or public safety
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Confirmation of release under conditions that neutralize danger
Crimes.Application_Factor: Compliance with conditions over time, disruption of social contacts
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Partial relaxation of conditions with continued oversight

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Threat to national security due to alleged membership in a terrorist group

Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Evidence relied on intelligence; some credibility concerns noted

Whether current release conditions are appropriate and proportionate

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Conditions must neutralize danger and be proportional to risk
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Conditions are overbroad and no longer justified due to changed circumstances
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Request for greater autonomy and reduced restrictions

Legal_Issue: Whether reasonable grounds existed to believe tax collection would be jeopardized by delay
Governing_Law: s. 225.2(2) of the Income Tax Act
Procedural_Stage: Review of ex parte jeopardy collection order
Evidence_Assessment: Assignment of Services MLM's most valuable asset to offshore company Wellgate with no Canadian assets
Burden_of_Proof: Crown must justify the jeopardy order; applicant bears burden to show lack of reasonable grounds
Credibility_Factor: Concerns over asset dissipation due to offshore transfer
Legal_Rule: A judge may authorize immediate tax collection under s. 225.2(2) if delay would jeopardize collection
Standard_of_Review: Reasonable grounds to believe jeopardy to collection
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of asset dissipation following transfer to offshore entity
Outcome_on_Merits: Jeopardy collection order upheld as justified
Key_Evidence_Considered: Transfer of assets to Wellgate, an offshore company without Canadian assets
Defendant_Response: Services MLM challenged the ex parte order, arguing lack of reasonable grounds and inadequate disclosure
Remedy_Requested: Review and cancellation of the ex parte jeopardy collection order
Outcome: Ex parte jeopardy collection order confirmed; challenge dismissed

Application_Facts: Alexandr Pikulin claimed asylum due to alleged persecution in Israel; the Refugee Protection Division rejected his claim
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal failed to analyze credibility and subjective fear of persecution; inadequate assessment of state protection and nature of persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of applicant's credibility and subjective fear; lack of proper evaluation of state protection
Credibility_Assessment: Inadequate credibility assessment by the tribunal
Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remanded for reconsideration by a different panel
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim with proper credibility and fear assessment
Legal_Standard_Applied: Justified, transparent, intelligible decision within acceptable range based on facts and law
Decision_Rationale: Decision lacked sufficient reasoning on credibility, subjective fear, state protection, and persecution

Violation_Type: Failure to provide adequate state protection assessment
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 101(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant fled Saint Lucia due to domestic abuse and sought asylum in Canada; challenged negative PRRA decision based on inadequate state protection assessment
Residency_Compliance: Compliant with Canadian immigration procedures at time of application
Procedural_Issue: PRRA Officer treated failure to seek state protection as fatal, relied on non-police agencies for protection, failed to properly consider country condition evidence
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports on Saint Lucia, applicant's testimony on domestic abuse
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer disregarded relevant country condition evidence
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision found unreasonable
Relief_Sought: Stay of removal, reevaluation of PRRA
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of PRRA by a different officer
Decision_Rationale: Officer's conclusion was not justified, transparent, or intelligible; fell outside acceptable range of outcomes due to errors in assessing state protection
Authority_Responsible: PRRA Officer, Federal Court (on judicial review)

Violation_Type: Failure to meet eligibility criteria for asylum
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to persecution in Mexico; testimony contained inconsistencies and lacked corroboration
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent testimony, lack of credible evidence
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review process, burden of proof on applicant
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, lack of corroborating evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroboration, failure to prove unavailability of state protection or impossibility of internal relocation
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant deemed not credible due to inconsistencies and lack of supporting evidence
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, no question certified
Relief_Sought: Grant of asylum, successful judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Certification of a question of law, reversal of asylum denial
Decision_Rationale: No reviewable error found; applicant failed to demonstrate unavailability of state protection or impossibility of internal flight alternative

Violation_Type: Failure to meet criteria for person in need of protection
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution due to past attacks and gender; evidence indicated fear stemmed from generalized crime in Haiti affecting all genders
Evidence_Used: Evidence showing generalized crime in Haiti, lack of gender-based persecution targeting the applicant personally
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence linking fear to Convention grounds; failure to demonstrate personal risk distinct from general population
Decision_Outcome: RPD concluded applicant was not a 'person in need of protection'
Outcome: Judicial review application dismissed
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a person in need of protection
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of RPD's rejection of asylum claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds
Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to prove persecution based on specific Convention grounds or a personal risk beyond generalized violence

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of immigration officer's decision on H&C application
Evidence_Assessment: Significant establishment in Canada over 13 years, hardship evidence
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compelling humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's long-term residence and integration in Canada
Legal_Rule: Standard of review is reasonableness; decision must be intelligible, transparent, justifiable, and within acceptable range
Grounds_for_Claim: Exemption from applying for permanent residence outside Canada based on H&C grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Length of stay in Canada, family ties, hardship if removed
Legal_Framework: Subsection 72(1) of IRPA, Federal Court review standards
Defendant_Response: Immigration officer denied application, citing insufficient grounds
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, personal affidavits, records of residence
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, application remitted to a different officer

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Jayasinghe applied for a Canadian visa; his military role, admissions about operations, and country reports indicated involvement in human rights abuses.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Allegation of breach of duty of fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Admissions, country reports, operational records, statements
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Jayasinghe's denials deemed inconsistent and implausible
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer’s decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Credible evidence supported reasonable belief of involvement in crimes against humanity or war crimes

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: War crimes involving human rights abuses
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to command role and credible abuse reports
Crimes.Risk_Type: Threat to international peace and security
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Admissions, country reports, operational patterns
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer reasonably questioned Jayasinghe's credibility

Crimes.Institutional_Action: Visa officer assessment and Federal Court review
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: State engaged in or tolerated torture

Application_Facts: PRRA officer excluded 20 documents deemed not 'new', despite letters from credible sources such as state officials providing significant corroboration of Mr. Elezi's claims.
Procedural_Issue: Exclusion of new evidence under subsection 113(a) without proper justification
Evidence_Used: 20 documents, including letters from credible sources like state officials
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider key corroborating evidence that was reasonably available or arose after the Board's rejection
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by the Board; PRRA application denied
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision quashed; matter remitted for a new hearing with a different officer
Relief_Sought: Acceptance of refugee claim and protection
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and a new PRRA assessment
Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether the PRRA officer correctly applied subsection 113(a) of the IRPA regarding new evidence
Decision_Rationale: The PRRA officer erred in excluding critical evidence that could significantly support the claimant's case, warranting a new hearing

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness and procedural fairness of visa denial
Evidence_Assessment: Lack of financial means, unstable employment, no travel history, family ties in Canada (fiancé and sisters), weak ties to Haiti
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate intent to return to home country
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's economic and familial ties to home country vs. destination country
Legal_Rule: Visa officers have discretion to deny visas if temporary residence intent is not sufficiently demonstrated
Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable decision, lack of procedural fairness (no interview)
Key_Evidence_Considered: Financial status, employment stability, travel history, family relationships in Canada and Haiti
Defendant_Response: Visa officer reasonably assessed risk of overstaying based on established criteria
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, personal circumstances, familial ties
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; decision upheld
Legal_Provision: Section of Immigration and Refugee Protection Act regarding temporary resident visas

Application_Facts: Applicant studied in Canada for four years; visa officer assumed strong ties to Canada without allowing applicant to respond to concerns about intent to leave
Residency_Compliance: Compliant with temporary status during studies
Procedural_Issue: Lack of opportunity to address concerns about intent to return to Colombia
Evidence_Used: Duration of study in Canada as indicator of weakened ties to home country
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider applicant's evidence of ties to Colombia; reliance on generalization
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; decision based on assumptions rather than credibility findings
Decision_Outcome: Application refused based on presumed inability to leave Canada
Outcome: Decision set aside
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by a different visa officer
Decision_Rationale: Visa officer relied on stereotype that prolonged stay in Canada severs foreign ties, without giving applicant chance to respond
Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer at Canadian visa office

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Paragraph 34(1)(f) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Mekonen was alleged to be a member of the Earth Liberation Front (ELF), an organization involved in terrorism or subversion.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to disclose CBSA and open-source documents used in decision-making; lack of definition of 'terrorism'
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by another officer
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Breach of procedural fairness due to non-disclosure and failure to define 'terrorism'

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach of procedural fairness in immigration decisions
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 34(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Mekonen denied opportunity to respond to allegations of ELF membership and associated terror activities
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Application refused due to procedural issues
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide relevant documents and define 'terrorism'
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of disclosure prevented meaningful response
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remittal for redetermination by different officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Duty of procedural fairness in administrative decisions
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer failed in duty to ensure fair process by withholding evidence and omitting legal definition

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in organization engaging in terrorism or subversion
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to association with group engaged in terrorism
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Organization assessed as involved in terrorist activities
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Long-term membership and leadership role in ELF
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Reasonable grounds found, but credibility undermined by procedural flaws
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Incomplete due to lack of disclosure and analysis
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility based on organizational affiliation
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Denial of permanent residency and inadmissibility to Canada

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Family members and possibly state actors

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Found adequate by Board despite corruption

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Membership in a particular social group (homosexuals)
Crimes.Credibility: Assessed as credible but insufficient to prove lack of state protection

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Board assessed applicant's failure to access state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient demonstration of efforts to seek protection

Legal_Issue: Did the Officer err by failing to exercise discretion and ignoring relevant evidence regarding deferral?
Outcome: Application dismissed, no questions certified
Legal_Provision: IRPA - enforcement of removal orders unless deferral requested with sufficient evidence
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged health concerns not formally submitted
Legal_Standard: Onus on applicant to provide justification for deferral
Application_Factor: Failure to submit formal request or evidence

Legal_Issue: Did the Officer err in law by failing to exercise discretion and ignoring relevant evidence?
Evidence_Assessment: Applicants failed to provide documentary evidence
Legal_Rule: Officers must enforce removal orders unless deferral is requested with sufficient evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged medical condition not formally raised
Key_Evidence_Considered: Officer's notes indicating no deferral request
Outcome: Court upheld Officer's decision
Legal_Provision: IRPA - timely enforcement of removal orders

Legal_Issue: Lawfulness and reasonableness of the issuance of a Disposal at Sea Permit in presence of TBTs
Governing_Law: International Convention on the Control of Harmful Anti-fouling Systems on Ships
Evidence_Assessment: Scientific opinions on TBT risks, compliance with Clean-up Standard, age and activity level of anti-fouling paint
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant (The Society) to demonstrate unreasonableness or illegality
Credibility_Factor: Scientific evidence regarding inactivity of TBTs due to age
Legal_Rule: Administrative decisions must be lawful, reasonable, and within statutory authority
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged failure by Minister to consider a ban on TBTs and potential environmental harm
Key_Evidence_Considered: Clean-up Standard compliance, age and degradation of TBT-containing paint
Legal_Framework: CEPA and related regulations governing vessel pollution and disposal at sea
Defendant_Response: Permit issued in accordance with law and scientific assessment
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to quash the permit decision
Outcome: Application dismissed; costs awarded to Respondents
Legal_Provision: CEPA, Vessel Pollution Regulations, International Convention on the Control of Harmful Anti-fouling Systems on Ships

Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness, unreasonable assessment of evidence
Evidence_Assessment: Officer failed to acknowledge submitted documents; did not explain lack of points for Experience and English Proficiency
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate eligibility; duty on officer to fairly assess evidence
Credibility_Factor: Applicant provided evidence of work experience and English proficiency
Legal_Rule: Officers must ensure procedural fairness and reasonably assess submitted evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Breach of duty of fairness, ignoring evidence, misleading requests
Key_Evidence_Considered: Work experience documentation, language proficiency evidence
Defendant_Response: Failed to justify decision or acknowledge receipt of documents
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, application forms, supporting credentials
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision overturned
Legal_Provision: Sections of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act relating to assessment criteria and procedural fairness

Legal_Issue: Whether Apotex's Notice of Allegation (NOA) sufficiently addresses non-infringement and invalidity claims
Evidence_Assessment: Apotex's NOA did not address the possibility of an in situ subcoating; relied on incorrect patent construction
Decision_Outcome: NOA declared insufficient; issuance of Notice of Compliance prohibited
Burden_of_Proof: On Apotex to justify non-infringement and invalidity claims in NOA
Credibility_Factor: Consistency of Apotex's arguments with prior litigation and NOA content
Legal_Rule: NOA must provide detailed legal and factual basis for non-infringement or invalidity allegations
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, as judicial review not full trial
Grounds_for_Claim: Non-infringement due to absence of defined subcoating; patent invalidity
Outcome_on_Merits: Apotex's claims not justified; issue estoppel applied
Key_Evidence_Considered: Content of Apotex's NOA; prior litigation findings
Defendant_Response: Apotex alleged non-infringement and invalidity in NOA
Remedy_Requested: Declaration of NOA insufficiency; prohibition on NOC issuance
Outcome: In favor of AstraZeneca; costs awarded
Legal_Provision: Sections of the Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations regarding NOA requirements

Legal_Provision_Violated: Rule 58(1), Rule 61, IRPA sections related to refugee claim procedures
Governing_Law: Baker v. Canada (Minister of Citizenship and Immigration)
Application_Facts: Jang family's PIF was submitted 7 days late; Board had valid contact information; contradictory notices issued by the Board
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide meaningful reasons for abandonment decision
Evidence_Used: Standard form indicating late PIF submission
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No explanation provided for abandonment despite available contact information
Insufficient justification for applying abandonment rule
Decision_Outcome: Claim declared abandoned by the Board
Outcome: Court set aside the Board's decision
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the abandonment decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of abandonment issue by a different panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement for meaningful reasons in decisions of significant impact
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to provide adequate reasoning; contact information negated automatic abandonment; important decisions require substantive justification

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada beyond the authorized period of stay
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of IRB over refugee claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Subjective fear dismissed due to delay
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness for credibility, reasonableness simpliciter for state protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Long delay in claiming refugee status; insufficient evidence of state protection failure

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after refugee claim rejection and issuance of removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Assessment of ongoing risk despite removal order
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to consider available evidence on state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear not adequately assessed; evidence ignored
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Risk of gender-based persecution and state protection
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness for credibility, reasonableness for state protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board erred in dismissing fear and underestimating state protection gaps in Jamaica

Crimes.Crime_Name: Domestic abuse (non-specific charges without more details, potential charges could include Assault, Criminal Harassment, Threatening Death under the Criminal Code of Canada)
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Not applicable in context of victimization
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Perpetrator had history of abusive behavior
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – credible threats and physical harm
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Ongoing risk upon return to country of origin

Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – crime occurred abroad and not prosecuted in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Criminal Code of Canada (potential charges: Assault, Criminal Harassment, Threatening Death)

Application_Facts: Applicant faced alleged threats from Sri Lankan authorities and Karuna group
Evidence_Used: Threats by Sri Lankan authorities and Karuna group
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Generalized risks rather than Convention grounds, inconsistent evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues found by the Board
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Balance of probabilities, more than a mere possibility of persecution or torture
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision was reasonable based on credibility concerns and lack of evidence linking threats to Convention grounds

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Threats related to refusal to participate in criminal activities

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No evidence of nationwide influence by perpetrator

Legal_Issue: Was the Board's decision that the applicant lacked credibility reasonable?
Outcome: The Board's decision was reasonable and within acceptable outcomes based on facts and law; no errors warrant Court intervention.
Credibility_Assessment: The Board identified multiple inconsistencies in the applicant's story, which cumulatively suggested a lack of credibility.
Evidence_Type: PIF, testimony, medical documents, corroborating documents
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in evidence, unreliable or hearsay documents
Evidence_Ignored: Medical and corroborating documents deemed unreliable or hearsay
Legal_Standard: The Board can draw negative inferences regarding credibility based on inconsistencies in evidence
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no certification of general importance question

Application_Facts: Shah claimed refugee status due to alleged Taliban persecution but provided inconsistent testimonies
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent accounts about when children were removed from school, difficulty recalling significant events
Evidence_Used: Testimony, PIF, psychological and corroborating evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Corroborating documents deemed unreliable or hearsay
Credibility_Assessment: Numerous inconsistencies in Shah's testimony cumulatively undermined credibility
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no question certified
Outcome: Board's decision upheld
Legal_Standard_Applied: The Board can draw negative inferences regarding credibility based on inconsistencies
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court
Decision_Rationale: Cumulative inconsistencies and lack of credible corroboration

Legal_Standard: Standard of review for H&C applications is reasonableness

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed her visa since 1995, made a false refugee claim in 2005, and applied for humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds in 2010
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national without valid immigration status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Made a false refugee claim in 2005
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Application for H&C consideration under IRPA
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether applicant must apply for permanent residence from outside Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Family support in Haiti, lack of substantial ties in Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of personal hardship or risk upon return to Haiti
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative – due to past false refugee claim and lack of credible hardship claims
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn officer's decision and grant H&C permanent residency
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Unusual or disproportionate hardship under Section 25(1) IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded no unusual or disproportionate hardship would occur upon departure; applicant has family support in Haiti and weak ties to Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: False refugee claim under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Humanitarian and compassionate application denial based on credibility and misrepresentation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant faces unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship justifying exemption despite prior fraud
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; H&C application denied
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Adverse – based on knowingly false refugee claim in 2005
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Historical immigration records, application documents, country condition information
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged hardship if returned to Haiti
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Prior misrepresentation and lack of personalized risk or hardship evidence
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration officer, reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: False refugee claim constitutes serious misrepresentation
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified – officer considered all relevant factors
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decision
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of non-compliance and fraud weighed heavily
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False refugee claim submitted in 2005

Legal_Issue: Was the Board's decision to reject the applicant's refugee claim based on lack of credibility reasonable?
Outcome: Application dismissed; no credible basis for claim under IRPA
Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned applicant's religious knowledge and concluded he was not a genuine Christian
Application_Error: Lack of credible evidence supporting religious belief
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness for credibility assessment; correctness for procedural fairness
Legal_Standard: Standard of review: reasonableness for evidence and credibility; correctness for procedural fairness
Application_Factor: Applicant's claimed religious persecution and refugee status

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of regulatory provision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD erred in interpreting 'time of application' under paragraph 117(9)(d) of the Regulations
Crimes.Governing_Law: Paragraph 117(9)(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, case remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration forms, declaration records
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to declare daughter’s birth during immigration process
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Ongoing obligation to update application post-initial filing
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to declare dependent after birth
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Interpretation of regulatory language
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timing of disclosure relative to application process
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Error in law found, remitted for reconsideration
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Yes

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to declare dependants under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of 'at the time of application'
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD erred in limiting 'application' to initial submission
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR), paragraph 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Timing of declaration of child's birth
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision set aside, remanded for reevaluation
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to disclose all dependants
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Obligation to disclose all family members throughout application process
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to declare newborn daughter before obtaining permanent residency
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Immigration forms, date of child's birth, timing of disclosure
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Official immigration documents, birth certificate

Crimes.Crime_Name: Residing without status in the United States
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of humanitarian and compassionate application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer's refusal was procedurally fair, unbiased, legally correct, and reasonable
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Risk, family ties, establishment, children's interests, mental health

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section on temporary resident status
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed visas and applied for humanitarian and compassionate grounds

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements in an application (potential, based on refusals to provide updates or discrepancies)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of humanitarian application denial
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Alleged procedural unfairness due to lack of opportunity to update information
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants failed to demonstrate expectation or significant new evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Illegal entry into the United States
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of humanitarian and compassionate application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness, incorrect legal test, unreasonable decision
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Extrinsic country reports, personal circumstances, hardship factors

Crimes.Crime_Name: Border document misrepresentation (if any documentation was misrepresented during entry attempts)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of humanitarian application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness, legal test application, reasonableness of decision
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misrepresentation in documentation during entry or application process

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose previous visa denial
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Immigration Officer erred in assessing the applicant's ties to India
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, paragraph 20(1)(b)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned applicant's intent to return to India
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Paragraph 20(1)(b), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient demonstration of ties to home country
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Perceived lack of strong ties to India despite evidence
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under section 72 of the Act
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider all relevant evidence of ties to India
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Patent unreasonableness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Higher salary in Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Immigration Officer erred in concluding insufficient ties to India
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, paragraph 20(1)(b)
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision quashed and remanded
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer doubted applicant's intention to leave Canada after authorized stay
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Paragraph 20(1)(b), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Lack of sufficient ties to home country (India)
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Focus on higher Canadian salary while ignoring countervailing ties
Crimes.Application_Error: Overemphasis on one factor (salary) and disregard of other evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Patent unreasonableness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Higher salary in Canada
